text: Our Vision: Be the preeminent banking partner for institutions with cross-border needs, a global leader in wealth management and a valued personal bank in our home market of the United States.

Priorities under 'Largely Complete' include Simplification (focusing on five core businesses, exiting 14 international consumer markets, and simplifying structure) and Culture & Talent (building a winning culture, investing in talent, and delivering One Citi).

Main Priorities for 2025 and 2026 include Transformation (relentless execution, regulatory remediation, modernizing infrastructure, data enhancements) and Enhancing Business Performance (maximizing global network, scaling wealth, targeting share gains, and growing the commercial banking segment).
$21.6B of revenues, up 3% YoY.
Record revenues in USPB and Wealth.
Expenses of $13.4B, efficiency ratio of 62% improved by ~490 bps YoY.
Positive operating leverage for Citi and across all businesses.
RoTCE of 9.1% up ~150 bps YoY.
CET1 Capital Ratio of 13.4%, ~130 bps above current regulatory minimum.
Returned ~$2.8 billion to common shareholders through buybacks & dividends.
Services has achieved 3 consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage.
Markets has achieved 4 consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage.
Banking has achieved 5 consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage.
Wealth has achieved 4 consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage.
USPB has achieved 10 consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage.
Services continued its momentum, with TTS gaining ~65 bps and Securities Services gaining ~100 bps of market share YoY.
Markets saw 12% revenue growth, with Equities revenues up 23% YoY and Fixed Income revenues up 8% YoY.
Banking achieved IB Wallet Share Gains, with IB Fees up 14% YoY and Advisory Fees up 84% YoY.
Wealth is executing on its strategy with Net New Investment Assets (NNIA) of $16.5B and Client Investment Assets up 16% YoY.
USPB is showing improving returns, with RoTCE at 12.9%, up ~740 bps YoY, and revenue up 2% YoY.
Business achievements include launching Citi Payments Express in 19 countries, supporting Equities and Prime growth, and signing a partnership with Palantir for Wealth.
USPB improved customer support with a Gen AI pilot and launched Flex Pay on Apple Pay.
Cross LOBs enhanced the institutional client planning tool for ~2K relationship managers.
Modernization efforts involved retiring or replacing 130 applications in 1Q25.
Expanded adoption of Gen AI tools resulted in 385K utilizations and ~220K automated code reviews.
Automated high-priority manual reconciliations and used Gen AI to detect unauthorized trading activity to improve FX surveillance.
The key benefits of these initiatives are enhancing top-line revenue growth, improving operating efficiency, and reducing risk while improving safety and soundness.
Revenues were up 3% YoY, driven by growth in each business, largely offset by a decline in All Other. Excluding divestiture impacts, revenues were also up 3% YoY.
Expenses were down 5% YoY, driven by a smaller FDIC special assessment and the absence of a restructuring charge. Excluding the FDIC special assessment and divestitures, expenses were down 3% YoY.
Credit Costs were $2.7 billion, primarily from net credit losses in cards and a firmwide ACL build, reflecting macroeconomic uncertainty.
RoTCE for the quarter was 9.1%.
Overall expenses in 1Q25 were down 5% YoY.
Technology/communication expenses were up 6% YoY due to continued investments in transformation, safety & soundness.
Other Expenses were down 10% YoY, driven by lower deposit insurance and legal-related charges, partially offset by higher professional fees and marketing.
Compensation and benefits & restructuring expenses were down 6% YoY, due to the absence of restructuring, productivity saves, and favorable FX impacts.
Citi had nearly $23B in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of 2.7% as of March 31.
Total EOP Consumer Loans were $386B, and Total Corporate Lending Exposure was $724B.
Revenues were up 3% YoY, driven by growth in TTS, with NII up 5% and NIR down 4%.
Expenses were down 3% YoY, largely driven by lower deposit insurance costs, severance, and legal expenses.
Credit Costs were $51 million, primarily from a net ACL build of $45 million.
Net Income for the quarter was $1.6 billion.
RoTCE was 26.2%.
Revenues up 12% YoY, driven by growth in both Fixed Income (up 8% YoY) and Equity markets (up 23% YoY).
Expenses up 2% YoY, driven by higher volume and other revenue-related expenses.
Credit Costs were $201 million, primarily related to Spread Products and a net ACL build.
Net Income was $1.8 billion.
RoTCE was 14.3%.
Revenues up 12% YoY, driven by growth in Investment Banking (up 14%) and mark-to-market on loan hedges.
Expenses down 12% YoY, driven by lower compensation from right-sizing the workforce.
Credit Costs were $214 million, consisting of a $180 million net ACL build and $34 million in net credit losses.
Net Income was $543 million.
RoTCE was 10.7%.
Revenue was up 24% YoY, driven by growth across Citigold, Private Bank, and Wealth at Work. NII was up 30% YoY and NIR was up 16% YoY.
Expenses were flat YoY, as benefits from right-sizing the workforce were offset by higher revenue-related expenses.
Credit Costs were $98 million, consisting of a $60 million net ACL build and $38 million in net credit losses.
Net Income was $284 million, and RoTCE was 9.4%.
Revenues up 2% YoY, driven by higher NII from loan growth in Branded Cards and higher deposit spreads in Retail Banking.
Expenses were flat YoY, as productivity savings were offset by higher advertising, marketing, and legal expenses.
Credit Costs were $1.8 billion, consisting of $2.0 billion in net credit losses, partially offset by a $172 million net ACL release.
Net Income was $745 million.
RoTCE was 12.9%.
Revenues down 39% YoY, driven by lower NII and mark-to-market valuation changes, as well as lower revenue from closed exits and wind-downs.
Expenses down 17% YoY, driven by a smaller FDIC special assessment, absence of a restructuring charge, and lower expenses from wind-down and exit markets.
Credit Costs were $359 million, consisting of $256 million in net credit losses and an ACL build of $103 million.
Revenues are guided to be ~$83.1-84.1 billion, with NII ex-Markets up 2-3%.
Expenses are guided to be slightly below $53.4 billion.
For Cost of Credit, Cards NCL rates are expected to be around the top of the 2024 ranges, with higher losses in 1H, and ACL build will be a function of the macroeconomic environment.
For Capital, a $20 billion common share repurchase program was authorized in January, with $1.75 billion repurchased in 1Q25 and a similar amount targeted for 2Q25.
Citi remains committed to continuing to improve returns over time.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties.
Actual results may differ materially due to factors such as macroeconomic conditions, geopolitical events, and regulatory changes.
These statements are based on current expectations and Citi does not undertake to update them.
For a full list of risk factors, refer to Citigroup's filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, including the 2024 Form 10-K.
Total average deposits show a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 4.2% since 1Q19.
Services average deposits show a CAGR of 5.5% since 1Q19.
Effective January 1, 2025, certain transaction processing fees paid by Citi are now presented as a contra-revenue within non-interest revenue, instead of an operating expense.
Prior periods have been conformed to reflect this change in presentation.
This change in presentation does not impact Citi's net income.

This slide provides definitions for key acronyms and financial terms used throughout the presentation, such as ACL (Allowance for Credit Losses), CET1 (Common Equity Tier 1), NII (Net Interest Income), RoTCE (Return on Average Tangible Common Equity), and USPB (U.S. Personal Banking).
